sn16.12:1.3: This is a stock series of propositions by non-Buddhists, raised here as a teaching method.
sn16.12:1.4: An awakened one, whether the Buddha or anyone else, exists after death, for example in an eternal state of Nirvana. | Here “realized one” (tathāgata) pertains to any arahant, as at SN 54.12. The Pali commentary says that a “living being” (satta) is meant. However, tathāgata and satta are exact verbal parallels: tathā (“real”) + gata (“come to the state of”) and sa (“real”) + tta (“state of”). Thus it seems likely that this was originally intended as a mere verbal gloss to explain the compound. That it does not mean just any sentient being is established at SN 22.86:1.5.
sn16.12:1.7: A sage ceases to exist at the time of death. This assumes there is an enduring “self” that is done away with.
sn16.12:1.10: This kind of “both A and not A” statements are not meant to be paradoxical or mystical. Rather, they represent some state that combines elements of both. For example, their body does not exist but their mind does.
sn16.12:1.13: Likewise, “neither A nor not A” is not meant to be a paradox, but to indicate something that cannot be characterized by the original term. For example, a sage persists after death in a subtle state that is not what we normally consider existence.
